intro: Lithospermum drummondii, commonly known as Drummond's lithosperm, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and arranged oppositely along the stem, while its fruit is a capsule that releases tiny seeds. Lithospermum drummondii is known for its medicinal properties, with some parts of the plant used traditionally in herbal remedies.
